subject: Self Care
title: Doomscrolling
description: A fast breakdown of Doomscrolling for builders.

hook.text: Bad news at 11 PM. You scrolled for two hours consuming disaster after disaster. You felt worse and couldn't stop.

buildup.text: Doomscrolling is compulsive consumption of negative news. The brain monitors threats, so bad news is hard to ignore.

discovery.text: Negativity bias makes bad news stickier than good news. Media algorithms amplify this because outrage drives engagement.

twist.text: Staying informed is healthy. Doomscrolling is not. The difference is intention and time limits. One is choice, one is compulsion.

climax.text: Check news once or twice daily, from trusted sources, for a set duration. Then close. Protect your evening hours.

punchline.text: Be informed, not immersed. Set limits on negative news.

quiz.question: Why is doomscrolling so difficult to stop?
options: Negativity bias makes the brain prioritize threats and bad news is stickier
Doomscrolling is not a real phenomenon
